title: 114_hr3313
content: The Act titled "Cyber Defense of Federal Networks Act of 2015" introduces cybersecurity plans under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Cyber Defense of Federal Networks Act of 2015 mandates the development of an intrusion detection and response plan by the Secretary, in coordination with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, to detect and remove intruders in agency information systems. The plan must be updated as necessary and does not apply to the Department of Defense or elements of the intelligence community. Definitions for "agency" and "cybersecurity risk" are provided in the section. The term 'information system' and 'intelligence community' are defined in relation to cybersecurity and communications integration. SEC. 231. ADVANCED INTERNAL DEFENSES. The Secretary will include advanced network security tools in the Department's efforts to diagnose and mitigate cybersecurity risks, improving visibility of network activity to detect and mitigate intrusions and anomalous activity in agencies' information systems. A plan will be developed to ensure these tools are available for use by each agency. The Secretary, in coordination with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will prioritize and update operational capabilities for network security monitoring tools within agency networks. They will also review and update metrics to measure security, including intrusion and incident detection and response times. The Secretary, in coordination with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will increase transparency on agency cybersecurity postures by adding more metrics to Federal Government performance websites. Additionally, technologies for deploying, operating, and maintaining agency networks will be maintained. Federal cybersecurity best practices are regularly assessed and implemented to secure agency information systems against intrusion and prevent data exfiltration. In this section, definitions are provided for key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "intrusion assessments," and "intrusion detection and response plan." The Comptroller General of the United States is required to conduct an assessment within three years of the enactment of this section. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the effectiveness of the Department's approach in securing agency information systems. The Secretary must submit an intrusion detection and response plan to Congress within six months of the enactment of this section, and provide annual updates thereafter. The Secretary must submit an intrusion detection and response plan to Congress, including findings of intrusion assessments, descriptions of advanced network security tools, information on cybersecurity best practices, and improved metrics. Definitions in the Homeland Security Act are also amended. The definitions in the Homeland Security Act, specifically regarding cybersecurity risk and incidents, are amended to clarify the scope of what constitutes a cybersecurity risk and incident. The term cybersecurity risk now includes threats to information systems and related consequences, excluding violations of consumer terms of service. An incident is defined as an occurrence that jeopardizes the integrity, confidentiality, or availability of information without lawful authority. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to clarify cybersecurity risk and incidents, defining incidents as occurrences that jeopardize information integrity, confidentiality, or availability without lawful authority. SEC. 3 outlines the duties of the Secretary of Homeland Security related to information security, including cybersecurity plans, advanced internal defenses, federal best practices, and assessment reports. Section 3553(b)(6) of title 44, United States Code, is amended to include providing incident detection, analysis, mitigation, and response information, disseminating homeland security information, compiling and analyzing data on agency information security, developing targeted risk assessments, and conducting operational evaluations for agency information systems. The curr_chunk involves coordinating with other agencies and private entities to assess and develop information security technologies. It also includes ensuring that policies are complementary with national security systems and directives issued by other agencies. The curr_chunk refers to policies and directives issued by the Secretary of Defense and the Director of National Intelligence. The curr_chunk focuses on directives and imminent threats. Section 3553 of title 44, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary to issue directives to agencies in response to information security threats, including terrorism, to protect agency information systems. The Secretary can issue directives to agencies to protect information systems from security threats or terrorism, with established procedures including thresholds and criteria. The Secretary can issue directives to agencies to protect information systems from security threats or terrorism, with established procedures including thresholds, privacy protections, notice to third parties, reasons for action, duration of directive, minimizing impact, and immediate notification to relevant authorities. The Secretary may authorize the use of protective capabilities for agency information systems in case of imminent threats, including terrorism, without prior consultation with the affected agency to ensure security. The Secretary can authorize protective measures for agency information systems in case of imminent threats, including terrorism, without prior consultation with the affected agency. This authority cannot be delegated to a lower-ranking official than an Assistant Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security. The Secretary must notify the Director and the head of each affected agency of any actions taken, along with the reasons, duration, and nature of the action. Any actions taken by the Secretary must comply with applicable law. The Secretary can direct protective measures to safeguard agency information from unauthorized access or address information security risks, including terrorism. This action can only be taken to protect agency information or information systems used by or on behalf of an agency. The Secretary must provide an annual report to Congress by February 1 detailing the actions taken to protect agency information and address security risks.
